ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Spaser in plasmonic nano-antenna evaluated by an analytical theory

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Surface plasmon amplification by the stimulated emission of radiation (spaser) in plasmonic nanocavities as a novel concept has quickly advanced in recent years. Understanding the nature and mechanism of the spaser system is important for both fundamental studies and the development of new applications. We theoretically investigate the spaser made from a plasmonic nano-antenna embedded with active gain media by using an analytical semiclassical theory. It incorporates the four-level atomic rate equations in association with the classical oscillator model for active materials and Maxwell’s equations for fields. The nano-antenna cavity has a large Purcell factor and low absorption loss which is beneficial for the realization of low-threshold spaser. We use the theory to uncover all the characteristics of this nanocavity spaser system, including the enhancement of the local electric field, gain, saturation phenomenon and lasing threshold. It is found that an important quantity named the cavity loss coupling strength coefficient can be explored to provide a new way to design the nanocavity precisely to reduce the absorption power density and enhance the spaser output power density simultaneously. The theory can be commonly used in understanding and designing various micro/nanolaser and spaser systems.

Body.Para: Future nanophotonics will most likely witness the development of tiny volume nanostructures and high integration logic devices which are able to combine the novel properties of materials and high intensity nanoscale coherent light source to forge new and interesting tunable functionalities. As a part of these researches, light-matter interaction at nanoscale has been extensively and intensively studied for many years [1–19] and it will surely continue to develop for a longer time. Although nanoscale coherent light source is still an experimentally and theoretically challenging subject, several studies have reported the capability to control light at nanoscale by using active nanostructures, such as the trapping and manipulation of photons in a resonant nanocavity [20–22], coherent emission, transport, and amplification of surface plasmons [23–25], giant local field enhancement [10, 26], compensation of metallic dissipation loss [8, 27] and amplification of gain [28, 29]. Towards this fundamental purpose, photonic crystal nanocavity lasers with gain media and surface plasmon amplification by stimulated emission of radiation (spaser) [1–14] have stood out as two prominent solutions.

In principle, it is never an easy thing to describe the light-matter interaction in a simple analytical way as the geometries of nanolasers are complicated and involve many subtle nanoscale morphologic features, although the properties and performance of nanolasers can be understood with the semiclassical physical model of harmonic oscillators coupled to electromagnetic field. With the help of powerful numerical simulation methods, e.g. finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method in combination with the atomic rate equations, the dipole approximation model and Maxwell’s equations, previous studies have investigated nanolasers in several realistic active dielectric and plasmonic systems [30–33]. Although technically accurate data of nanolaser performances can be obtained from time-consuming of numerical calculations, a clear physics image about all important issues will be difficult to extract directly. Hence, a comprehensive and still quantitatively accurate analytical theory can greatly help to better understand, explain, and predict nanolaser systems.

Plasmonic nano-antennae with tiny gap embedded with active gain media have been widely studied due to their simple geometry and the capabilities of high local field enhancement in the visible/near infrared (NIR) range [15–19]. Thus they are potential candidates for the spaser and nanolaser systems. Here, we present our efforts to develop an easy-to-understand analytical semiclassical theory for nano-antenna nanolasers by taking into account power density conservation and spontaneous and stimulated emission. Starting from the basic atomic rate equation in association with the classical oscillator model, the theory has a final form looking similar to conventional lasers [34] and it can explain the spaser effect more clearly and precisely.

Section1.Heading: Results
Section1.Para:
As illustrated in Fig. 1a, the plasmonic nanocavity used to excite the spaser is a gold nano-antenna with a tiny gap, providing for plasmon resonance modes. The gap is filled with silica doped with active materials, which are described by general four-level atomic system, providing for lasing gain to compensate the loss of the nanocavity. The geometries of the Au nano-antenna are chosen so that the plasmon nanocavity resonance peak is located at 860 nm. The resonance mode has a high quality (Q) factor [3] of 37, and a modal volume [3] of V
m =0.00786(λ/n)3, where n is the refractive index of silica (n=1.45). The high Q factor and deep sub-wavelength nanoscale V
m give rise to a high Purcell factor [4, 35] F=358 or greatly enhanced emission rate, which is usually associated with micro-cavities. This chosen mode should experience low dissipation loss, which is essential to achieving low-threshold spaser. Hence we focus on this particular mode for the rest of our investigation.
Fig. 1
Schematic plot of the light-matter interaction of a general four-level atomic system with plasmonic nano-antennae. (a) Geometry of the plasmonic nano-antenna, which is composed by two gold arms and silica doped with four-level atoms as active materials inside the central tiny gap. Each atom is modeled as a radiation dipole. (b) Schematic of a general four-level atomic system which describes the spontaneous and stimulated radiation and various atomic transition parameters. The straight and dashed lines correspond to the radiative and nonradiative transitions

The structure as schematically illustrated in Fig. 1, can describe the gain and loss process happening in a general optical nanocavity very well. The length (L), width (W) and height (H) of each Au nano-antenna arm are 200 nm, 100 nm, and 100 nm, respectively, so the cavity volume is V 0=4.1×10−3 μm. The gap (D) between the two arms of nano-antenna is 10 nm and doped with active materials with total population density N 0 being 1026 m−3. When electrons are pumped from the ground-state level with a constant pump rate by optical or electrical pumping, spontaneous emission arises at the initial moment. Due to the feedback effect by the surface plasmon resonance of the Au nano-antenna, it causes stimulated emission until a steady-state is achieved. The schematic diagram of the atomic system is shown in Fig. 1b with all the transition channels explicitly noticed, where the level One and Two are the lower and upper lasing levels. According to studies being reported [18], the local electric field inside the tiny gap of nano-antenna is nearly uniform. In addition, the active materials can be treated as a set of dipoles.

In our theory, we consider atomic transitions in the spaser system quantum mechanically and adopt the model of atomic rate equations to describe these transitions. The occupation numbers of electrons at the atomic levels at each spatial point vary according to the following atomic rate equations [20–23, 34]:
1
$$\begin{aligned} &{dN_{3} / dt = W_{P}N_{0} - N_{3} / \tau_{32},} \end{aligned}$$
2
$$\begin{aligned} &{dN_{2} / dt = N_{3} / \tau_{32} + \frac{1}{\hbar \omega_{a}}\frac{E_{l}\cdot\partial P_\mathrm{at}}{\partial t} - N_{2} / \tau_{21},} \end{aligned}$$
3
$$\begin{aligned} &{dN_{1} / dt = N_{2} / \tau_{21} - \frac{1}{\hbar \omega_{a}}\frac{E_{l}\cdot\partial P_\mathrm{at}}{\partial t} - N_{1} / \tau_{10},} \end{aligned}$$
4
$$\begin{aligned} &{dN_{0} / dt = N_{1} / \tau_{10} - W_{P}N_{0}. } \end{aligned}$$

Equations (1) to (4) mean that an external excitation mechanism pumps electrons from the ground-state level (N 0) to the third level (N 3) at a certain pump rate (W
P ). After a short lifetime (τ 32), these excited electrons transfer nonradiatively down to the upper lasing level, i.e. the second level (N 2). The electrons can be transferred from the upper to the lower lasing level, i.e. the first level (N 1), by both spontaneous and stimulated emission. Finally, the electrons transfer quickly and nonradiatively from the first level (N 1) to the ground-state level (N 0). The lifetimes and energies of the upper and lower lasing levels are τ 21, E 2 and τ 10, E 1, respectively, where τ 21 is greater than τ 10 and τ 32. The center frequency of the radiation is ω
a =(E 2−E 1)/ħ. E
l is the local electric field in the cavity, P at is the electric polarization of atoms, and the term
$\frac{1}{\hbar \omega_{a}}\frac{E_{l}\cdot\partial P_{\mathrm{at}}}{\partial t}$ is the induced radiation rate or excitation rate depending on its sign. As the electronic transfer excitation and the system reaches gradually the steady-state described by dN
i /dt=0.

We handle the radiation of electromagnetic field classically, whose behavior follows Maxwell’s equations, and the interaction between atoms and fields can be thus treated semiclassically. Following the classical harmonic oscillator model, the polarization P at in the presence of an electric field obeys locally the following equation of motion:
5
$$\begin{aligned} &{d^{2}P_\mathrm{at}(t) / dt^{2} + \Delta \omega_{a}dP_\mathrm{at}(t) / dt + \omega_{a}^{2}P_\mathrm{at}(t)} \\ &{\quad = \varGamma_{a}\Delta N(t)E_{l}(t),} \end{aligned}$$ where Δω
a is the linewidth of atomic transition frequency and Γ
a is the coupling strength of the polarization to the external electric field. The expression of Γ
a is 3ω

According to the power density conservation, the power density stored by the upper lasing level p in equals the sum of the output power density p out, the absorption power density by the cavity p abs and the loss of spontaneous emission power density p loss-spo. The output power density and the absorption power density constitute the loss of cavity power density p loss-cav. The above relationship can be expressed as p in=p out+p abs+p loss-spo and p loss-cav =p out+p abs. It means that if the loss power density of cavity p loss-cav is larger than the absorption power density of the metallic nanocavity p abs, there is a net power output from the cavity.

Due to the electronic pumping, the power density, which can be witnessed and used by the third level, can be written as p pump=W
P
N 0 ħω 30, where ω 30 is the transition frequency between N 0 and N 3. We introduce a parameter called quantum efficiency η qe so that the storage power density by the upper lasing level is p in=η qe×p pump. As is known, the loss power of the cavity is proportional to
$\omega_{r}\varepsilon_{0}E_{l}^{2}V_{m} / Q$ , where ω
r is the resonance frequency of the cavity and this is the standard definition of the Q factor of a resonant cavity. We bring in another parameter called the cavity loss coupling strength coefficient η
F , which strongly depends on the geometric and material parameters of the cavity. The total loss power of the cavity can be written as
$P_{\mathrm{loss}\mbox{-}\mathrm{cav}} = \eta_{F} \times \omega_{r}\varepsilon_{0}E_{l}^{2}V_{m} / Q$ and the loss power density is p loss-cav=P loss-cav/V 0. It is obvious that a larger value of η
F means the easier loss of energy power from the cavity. The spontaneous emission power is only relevant to the population of upper lasing level, and we can get the spontaneous emission power density in the follow expression: p spo=N 2,ss
ħω
a /τ 21.

We notice that the spontaneous emission power is proportional to the upper lasing level population, however, not all of the spontaneous emission power leaves the cavity, most is either used to excite stimulated emission or absorbed by the cavity. The escaped spontaneous emission power density from the cavity can be defined as p loss-spo=η spo×p spo, where η spo is called the loss spontaneous emission efficiency. Obviously a larger value of η spo means the stronger loss of spontaneous emission power from the cavity, and simultaneously less conversion of this power into the useful laser energy power for the cavity. Considering the above description, we get
6
$$ \eta_\mathrm{qe} \times p_\mathrm{pump} = \eta_{F} \times \omega_{r}\varepsilon_{0}E_{l}^{2}V_{m} / QV_{0} + \eta_\mathrm{spo} \times p_\mathrm{spo}. $$

The above formulas can be combined together for a solution for various optical properties of the spaser system, after some tedious but straightforward algebraic manipulations. We start from the quantity of atomic polarizability χ at, and for the sake of simplicity of discussion, we define four parameters as follows:
7a
$$\begin{aligned} &{\varUpsilon_{0} = \bigl[ 4\omega_{a}^{2} ( \omega_{a} - \omega_{r} )^{2} + \omega_{r}^{2}\Delta \omega_{a}^{2} \bigr] / \Delta \omega_{a},} \end{aligned}$$
7b
$$\begin{aligned} &{\varUpsilon_{1} = QV_{0}\eta_\mathrm{spo} \omega_{a}\varepsilon_{0}\varUpsilon_{0},} \end{aligned}$$
7c
$$\begin{aligned} &{\varUpsilon_{2} = QV_{0}\varGamma_{a}W_{P}N_{0} \omega_{r} ( \eta_\mathrm{spo}\omega_{a} \tau_{10} - \eta_\mathrm{qe}\omega_{30} \tau_{21} ) } \\ &{\phantom{\varUpsilon_{2} =}{}- 2V_{m} \eta_{F}\omega_{a} \varepsilon_{0}\varUpsilon_{0},} \end{aligned}$$
7d
$$\begin{aligned} &{\varUpsilon_{3} = 2\varGamma_{a}W_{P}N_{0}V_{m} \eta_{F}\omega_{a}\omega_{r} ( \tau_{21} - \tau_{10} ).} \end{aligned}$$ The imaginary part of the atomic polarizability
$\chi_{\mathrm{at}}^{\prime\prime}$ can be written as [36]
8
$$ \chi_\mathrm{at}^{\prime\prime} = - \Bigl( \varUpsilon_{2} + \sqrt{\varUpsilon_{2}^{2} - 4\varUpsilon_{1} \varUpsilon_{3}}\, \Bigr) / 2\varUpsilon_{1}, $$ Eq. (8) represents the absorbing (or amplifying) part of the atomic response. The real part of the atomic polarizability
$\chi_{\mathrm{at}}'$ and the local electric field intensity inside the nano-antennae gap can be written, respectively, as
9
$$\begin{aligned} &{\chi_\mathrm{at}' = 2\omega_{a} ( \omega_{r} - \omega_{a} )\chi_\mathrm{at}^{\prime\prime} / \omega_{r}\Delta \omega_{a},} \end{aligned}$$
10
$$\begin{aligned} &{E_{l}^{2} = \frac{ ( \eta_\mathrm{qe} \times \hbar \omega_{30} - \eta_\mathrm{spo} \times \hbar \omega_{a} )W_{P}N_{0}}{ ( \eta_{F} \times V_{m} / QV_{c} - \eta_\mathrm{spo} \times \chi_\mathrm{at}^{\prime\prime} / 2 )\omega_{r}\varepsilon_{0}}.} \end{aligned}$$ If the radiation frequency ω
a equals the cavity resonance frequency ω
r , the expression equations will become much simpler.

Until now, we have got the analytical semiclassical theory for quantitatively describing the spaser system and the theoretical model has considered all the controllable parameters. It is a generic model enabling us to solve and explain a variety of complex spaser and nanolaser systems.

Section1.Heading: Discussion
Section1.Para:
We use the analytical semiclassical theory to investigate the relationship between the spaser properties and the variable parameters as well as the probable external excitation parameters. Overall physical images are collected from each individual parameter while keeping fixed the intrinsic characteristics of the nanocavity as the same. We suppose the radiation frequency is ω
a =2.19×1015 Hz and the corresponding wavelength is 860 nm, which is close to the resonance wavelength of the cavity. Considering the mature artificial atom technology [37], it is lightly feasible to manufacture this type of atoms in experiments. The linewidth of the transition frequency Δω
a is around 0.04ω
a . The lifetime τ 10, τ 21 and τ 32 are chosen as 1 ns, 10 ns and 1 ns, respectively. The coupling strength of P at to the external electric field Γ
a is taken to be 10−4 C2/kg.

Although the field in a gap antenna can be easily calculated from any commercial software, we still need a physical picture to understand the spaser system. In the above derivation of the analytical semiclassical theory, we assume that the local electric field E
l within the plasmonic nanocavity is a constant. This approximation is reasonable for a nanocavity whose size is much smaller than the radiation wavelength, e.g., the nano-antenna system in [18]. With this approximation, the semiclassical nanolaser theory can be applicable to a general nanolaser system with sufficient precision.

The three-dimensional (3D) surface contour maps of the local electric field (Figs. 2a and 2b) and
$\chi_{\mathrm{at}}^{\prime\prime}$ (Figs. 2c and 2d), which can directly describe the gain and loss of the system, are shown in Fig. 2 as pumping rate W
P , loss spontaneous emission efficiency η spo and cavity loss coupling strength coefficient η
F are varied by increments. Meanwhile, we fix η
F =3 in Figs. 2a and 2c and η spo=6 % in Figs. 2b and 2d, respectively.

The dependence of local electric field on W
P together with η spo (Fig. 2a) and on W
P together with η
F (Fig. 2b) are found to correlate very well with Eq. (10). It increases with W
P and decreases with η spo and η
F . If most of the spontaneous emission does not participate in the lasing action, which corresponds to a large η spo, the local electric field can achieve saturation with an increase of W
P (Fig. 2a). According to our calculations, the smaller η
F induces a larger local electric field due to slower loss of energy power from the cavity (Fig. 2b). However, the smaller η
F also corresponds to a huge cavity loss by the plasmonic nano-antenna’s absorption due to a large local electric field (Fig. 2b) and causes the lower output power density.

The huge cavity loss by the plasmonic nano-antenna’s absorption is a serious problem in plasmonic systems and the embedded active materials may compensate the loss or even amplify the input light signal. Although it is a complex expression of
$\chi_{\mathrm{at}}^{\prime\prime}$ by Eq. (8), its increase with the increase of η spo can be seen clearly in Fig. 2d. Due to the impact of pumping rate, the variation tendency with respect to η
F is not obvious (Fig. 2d). However, after the careful analysis with the calculation, especially when the pumping rate is large enough, we can find that
$\chi_{\mathrm{at}}^{\prime\prime}$ increases with η
F . This means that a larger local electric field does not necessarily induce a larger gain for a spaser nanocavity, but the local electric field depends on the competition between absorption and gain within the plasmonic nanocavity.

No matter whether in the conventional laser or in the spaser, the population difference saturation restricts the performance of laser output. The relationship between population difference (ΔN=N 2−N 1) saturation and pumping rate are shown in Figs. 3a and 3b while η spo and η
F are varied by increments, and we fix η
F =3 in Fig. 3a and η spo=6 % in Fig. 3b. The influence of η spo on the population difference (Fig. 3a) is not obvious as the loss power density caused by spontaneous emission can be compensated by the increase of pumping rate. Moreover, it is reasonable to get a larger ΔN with the increase of η
F because a larger η
F also causes a larger
$\chi_{\mathrm{at}}^{\prime\prime}$ (Figs. 2d and 3b). Writing at this point, we might as well think about the challenges toward a better spaser system. It is clear that η
F is a quantity pivotal to the nanocavity and its effects on the gain, population difference and the local electric field of the spaser system are different. These three characteristics compete with each other. All of them also act together to shape and determine the performance of the spaser system.

It is difficult to calculate the absorption power density of the complicated plasmonic nanocavity via the semiclassical analytical theory. However, we can draw support from the total loss power density p loss-cav of the nanocavity, which is composed of p out and p abs, to understand the physical images underlying the spaser system, because it is a relatively easy job to calculate p abs in a complex structure by means of numerical calculation, e.g., the FDTD method. The stronger loss of spontaneous emission power from the cavity means less conversion of this power into the useful laser energy power of the cavity, and it also causes less p loss-cav out of the cavity, which obviously enhances with the increase of pumping rate (Fig. 4a). To better understand the performance of the spaser, it is desirable to have a detail study of the relation between p loss-cav and η
F . According to Fig. 4c, all the curves for various values of η
F overlap almost each other. This means that there is no sensitive correlation between p loss-cav and η
F in the current nano-antenna spaser system no matter how large the pumping rate is (Figs. 4b and 4c). This means that when the pumping rate and active materials are fixed, the threshold depends on the absorption of the nanocavity, which is well-known. However, considering that there is no sensitive relation between p loss-cav and η
F , while the absorption loss p abs strongly depends on η
F , one can design the nanocavity carefully to obtain a lower p abs without changing p loss-cav and get a larger output power density p out.

Based on the FDTD calculation, we can obtain the linear relationship between single-dipole emission power P 0 and the absorption of the cavity P abs(p abs=N 0 P abs) (Fig. 4d). The single-dipole emission power is an external parameter related with the pumping rate. The initial power density then can be written as p in=N 0 P 0 and the pumping rate can be written as W
P =P 0/η qe×ħω 30. From Eq. (10) we can find
$E_{l}^{2}$ is proportional to the pumping rate. These results can introduce a novel concept that the threshold of the plasmonic nano-antenna spaser system not only depends on the absorption loss of the nanocavity, which is the characteristic of the conventional laser theory, but also strongly depends on the geometric and material parameters of the cavity, as the absorption is deeply related to the local electric field, in a form of
$p_{\mathrm{abs}} \propto E_{l}^{2}$ for the plasmonic nano-antenna system.

In conclusion, we have presented a simple while rigorous analytical semiclassical theory to solve the spaser properties of an active plasmonic nanocavity made from Au nano-antenna embedded with active materials inside the tiny gap. The key ingredient in the theory is how to construct a power density conservation formalism to deal with the energy exchange between active materials and fields, light emission, and spaser performance in the plasmonic nanocavity. The theory allows us to uncover all the characteristics of this nanocavity spaser system, which are well known in the conventional laser system, e.g. the enhancement of the local electric field, gain, the saturation phenomenon and the threshold. We find that the cavity loss coupling strength coefficient η
F is an important physical quantity in shaping and determining the performance of spaser. In addition, the cavity loss power density p loss-cav is almost independent of η
F while the absorption power density p abs strongly depends on η
F . Therefore, one can design the nanocavity carefully to obtain a lower p abs without changing p loss-cav for a larger output power density p out. Further design of high performance spaser devices in the framework of this theory can be expected. As this universal theory involves many basic parameters, it is expected that the theory can open up a broad window to understand, predict, and design many different microlaser, nanolaser, and spaser systems.
